title: Day 1194

# Day 1194

![Usury sucks, save in bitcoin instead of chasing yield on your savings via bonds (unless of course you like getting your life savings debased)](https://miro.medium.com/1*-QO3Y8OFLMu-d9ErGVdWwQ.png)

When you wake up, give yourself some grace. Thank God for another day.
Realize the present is a gift, the past a memory, and the future uncertain.
So make do with what you got and enjoy it.

Shift your framing from the pain of what you will face in the day,
to how great the outcome will feel after completing something hard.
Even if the hard thing is as simple as getting out of bed
when the weight of everything says stay down.

Some days you'll have to grit your teeth just to make it through,
and others will open like sunflowers, full of warmth, ease, and laughter.
But either way, you're still here. That's something.
That's everything.

Play the cards you're dealt.
Deal in the system you live in.
But don't forget,
you didn't build this deck.
And if it feels rigged sometimes,
maybe it is.

That doesn't mean fold.
It means stay aware.
Stay principled.
And if you know things could be better,
don't just accept them as they are.

Because some systems we live under don't just _happen._
They are built. Designed. Structured.
By people, for power.

Take money, for example.
We're told it's neutral. A tool.
But that's not the whole story.

See, money itself doesn't do anything.
It's inert.
Unlike labor or land, it doesn't produce value by itself.
So if I lend you money and charge you more to get it back,
I'm profiting off time, not effort.

I didn't till the land.
I didn't forge the metal.
I just waited.

In that sense, usury feels parasitic... because it is.
It's the extraction of value from someone else's need,
not the creation of value through mutual benefit.

Thomas Aquinas argued that charging interest is a sin against justice.
Why?
Because it's like selling the same thing twice,
first the principal, and then time.
And you're exploiting the borrower's necessity.
If someone borrows, it's often because they're in need.
That makes interest a kind of moral hazard:
the lender profits more when the borrower suffers longer.
There's a twisted incentive structure.

But we live in a world where that's been normalized.
Credit cards with 20+% interest.
Payday loans that destroy families.
Mortgage debt, student debt, medical debt, the list goes on...
a mountain of pressure on the average person
just to stay afloat.

It doesn't have to be this way.
There are people building lifeboats.
There are ideas like Bitcoin, like mutual aid, like localism...
that challenge the whole structure.
That ask, "What if value came from effort again?
What if you didn't need to sell your future just to survive today?"

I'm not saying it's easy.
You'll still have to work in the world as it is.
But you don't have to surrender to it.

Wake up with gratitude.
Face the day with courage.
And plant seeds of the world you want to see.

Because some of us were born into the house of usury.
But that doesn't mean we have to keep the lights on forever.

My 2 sats?
